byline.contributor: Anne Barnard reported from Beirut, and Karam Shoumali from Istanbul. Maher Samaan contributed reporting from Beirut, and Eric Schmitt from Washington.
byline.original: By ANNE BARNARD and KARAM SHOUMALI

abstract: Syrian conflict is edging closer to full-blown proxy war between United States and Russia; insurgent forces are receiving large amounts of American-made antitank missiles, even as Russia increases airstrikes against them.
lead_paragraph: Rebel commanders say that since Russian airstrikes began, antitank missiles are being readily delivered for the first time, raising morale but making a diplomatic settlement even more unlikely.

headline.main: U.S. Weaponry Is Turning Syria Into Proxy War With Russia
headline.print_headline: U.S. Weaponry Is Turning Syria Into Proxy War

snippet: Rebel commanders say that since Russian airstrikes began, antitank missiles are being readily delivered for the first time, raising morale but making a diplomatic settlement even more unlikely.

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations
